question: Concentration expressed as Percentage by Weight (w/w %) is given by formula
Concentration expressed as Percentage by Volume (v/V %) is given by formula
Concentration expressed as Percentage of Mass by Volume (w/V %) is given by formula
Mole fraction of A in a binary solution is given by (n<sub>A</sub> = no of moles of A, n<sub>B</sub> = no of moles of B)
Molarity (M) is defined as
options: \frac{\text{no of moles of Solute}}{\text{Volume of Solvent (in mL)}}
\frac{\text{no of moles of Solute}}{\text{Volume of Solvent (in L)}}
\frac{\text{no of moles of Solute}}{\text{Volume of Solution (in mL)}}
\frac{\text{no of moles of Solute}}{\text{Volume of Solution (in L)}}
answer: \frac{\text{no of moles of Solute}}{\text{Volume of Solution (in L)}}

question: Molality (m) is defined as
options: \frac{\text{no of moles of Solute}}{\text{Weight of Solvent (in g)}}
\frac{\text{no of moles of Solute}}{\text{Weight of Solvent (in kg)}}
\frac{\text{no of moles of Solute}}{\text{Volume of Solution (in mL)}}
\frac{\text{no of moles of Solute}}{\text{Volume of Solution (in L)}}
answer: \frac{\text{no of moles of Solute}}{\text{Weight of Solvent (in kg)}}

question: Number of gram equivalents of solute is defined as
options: \frac{\text{mass of Solute (in kg)}}{\text{Volume of Solute (in mL)}}
\frac{\text{mass of Solute (in kg)}}{\text{Volume of Solute (in L)}}

question: Normality (N) is defined as
options: \frac{\text{no of gm Equivalents of Solute}}{\text{Volume of Solution (in L)}}
\frac{\text{no of gm Equivalents of Solute}}{\text{Volume of Solution (in mL)}}
\frac{\text{no of gm Equivalents of Solute}}{\text{Volume of Solvent (in mL)}}
\frac{\text{no of moles of Solute}}{\text{Volume of Solution (in L)}}
answer: \frac{\text{no of gm Equivalents of Solute}}{\text{Volume of Solution (in L)}}

question: Molarity (M) is defined as
options: \frac{\text{mass of Solute (in gms)} \times 1000}{\text{mol-wt of Solute} \times \text{Volume of Solution (in L)}}
\frac{\text{mass of Solute (in gms)} \times 1000}{\text{mol-wt of Solute} \times \text{Volume of Solution (in mL)}}
\frac{\text{mass of Solute (in Kg)} \times 1000}{\text{mol-wt of Solute} \times \text{Volume of Solution (in L)}}
\frac{\text{mass of Solute (in gms)}}{\text{mol-wt of Solute} \times \text{Volume of Solution (in mL)}}
answer: \frac{\text{mass of Solute (in gms)} \times 1000}{\text{mol-wt of Solute} \times \text{Volume of Solution (in mL)}}

We express concentration of very dilute solutions by ppm which equals
options: ppm(\text{by volume}) = \frac{\text{Volume of Solute}}{\text{Volume of Solvent}} \times 10^6
ppm(\text{by volume}) = \frac{\text{Volume of Solute}}{\text{Volume of Solution}} \times 10^6
ppm(\text{by volume}) = \frac{\text{Volume of Solute}}{\text{Volume of Solvent}} \times 10^4
ppm(\text{by volume}) = \frac{\text{Volume of Solute}}{\text{Volume of Solution}} \times 10^4
answer: ppm(\text{by volume}) = \frac{\text{Volume of Solute}}{\text{Volume of Solution}} \times 10^6

question: The elevation in boiling point of a solvent due to addition of a nonvolatile solute is given by (K<sub>b</sub> = Ebullioscopic constant, m = molality)
tip: Adding salt to curry, increases the boiling point of water cooking the curry more effectively. Note: Vant Hoff factor need to be included for correction

question: The depression in freezing point of a solvent due to addition of a nonvolatile solute is given by (K<sub>f</sub> = cryoscopic constant, m = molality)
tip: This is how Kulfis are cooled. Ice at 0°C is added to a box. If we directly put the Kulfi metal molds, kulfi doesn’t freeze as its freezing point is well below 0°C. Salt is added to ice, which melts it. To melt itself ice requires heat, so it sucks heat away from the kulfi molds. Now the salt-ice slush temp drops to -10°C solidifying the kulfi. Note: Vant Hoff factor need to be included for correction

question: Osmotic pressure of solution is given by (d = density of solution, R = universal gas constant, T = Temperature, M<sub>B</sub> = molar mass of solute)
Van’t Hoff factor (i) is given by
options: \frac{\text{Number of particles initially}}{\text{Number of particles after association or dissociation}}
\frac{\text{Number of particles initially}}{2 * \text{Number of particles after association or dissociation}}
\frac{2 * \text{Number of particles after association or dissociation}}{\text{Number of particles initially}}
\frac{\text{Number of particles after association or dissociation}}{\text{Number of particles initially}}
answer: \frac{\text{Number of particles after association or dissociation}}{\text{Number of particles initially}}

Molal Depression constant (K<sub>f</sub>) equals (M<sub>A</sub> = molar mass of solvent,T<sub>f</sub><sup>°</sup> = freezing point of solvent, ΔH<sub>f</sub>  = molar enthalpy of fusion)
Choose the correct option for minimum boiling azeotrope
options: Boiling point higher than pure components
Boiling point lower than pure components
Liquid and Vapour at different composition
answer: Boiling point lower than pure components
